Description: Creates summary data and stores it in a summary index for faster searches
Splunk SPL Example: | summaryindex spool=f index=summary_idx | stats count by host
ESQL Example/Workaround: Use Transform API or Ingest Pipelines
Notes: ESQL doesn't have summary indexes; use Elasticsearch's transform feature or ingest pipelines for pre-aggregation

Description: Combines results from two searches based on common fields
Splunk SPL Example: search index=web | join sessionid [search index=app | fields sessionid, userid]
ESQL Example/Workaround: Use multiple FROM clauses with WHERE conditions
Notes: ESQL doesn't support JOIN yet; workaround with multiple queries or use regular Elasticsearch queries with terms lookup

Description: Adds statistical information to each event without changing the number of events
Splunk SPL Example: | eventstats avg(response_time) as avg_resp by host
ESQL Example/Workaround: FROM logs | STATS avg_resp = AVG(response_time) BY host | EVAL ...
Notes: ESQL STATS groups data; for inline stats, need separate aggregation query or use regular ES aggregations

Description: Extracts and manipulates JSON data within events
Notes: ESQL has native JSON field access using dot notation

Description: Reusable search fragments defined as macros
ESQL Example/Workaround: Create saved queries or use Elasticsearch templates
Notes: ESQL doesn't support macros; use saved queries, Elasticsearch query templates, or application-level abstraction

Description: Appends results from a second search to the first
ESQL Example/Workaround: Use UNION in future versions or multiple queries
Notes: ESQL doesn't support APPEND yet; combine at application level or wait for UNION support

Description: Groups events into transactions based on common fields and time proximity
ESQL Example/Workaround: Use EQL sequence queries for time-based event correlation
Notes: Use EQL sequence queries for transaction-like behavior, but not as flexible as Splunk's transaction command

Description: Loads data from external CSV files or lookup tables
ESQL Example/Workaround: Use Elasticsearch indices or enrich policies
Notes: Load CSV data into Elasticsearch indices or use enrich processor in ingest pipelines

Description: Performs a search within another search
Splunk SPL Example: search index=web NOT [search index=blocked_ips | fields ip]
ESQL Example/Workaround: Use multiple queries with application logic
Notes: ESQL doesn't support subsearches; implement with multiple queries and application-level logic

Description: Triggers alert actions like email, webhook, or custom notifications directly from search pipeline
Splunk SPL Example: | alert_actions email "to=admin@company.com subject='Alert' message='High CPU detected'"
ESQL Example/Workaround: Use Elasticsearch Watcher or Kibana Alerting
Notes: ESQL doesn't support inline alert actions; use Watcher API, Kibana alerting rules, or external alerting systems

Description: Sends HTTP requests to external APIs as part of search pipeline
ESQL Example/Workaround: Use Elasticsearch Watcher webhook action or external processing
Notes: Configure webhook actions in Watcher or process ESQL results in application layer to trigger webhooks
